REVIEW

Web.com AI Review

Inherited a Web.com client from 2019. "Can't we just modernize this?" Three hours in, I realized: no. The templates, the AI, the entire platform feels stuck in 2015. At $20-30/month, you're paying legacy prices for legacy tech. Only reason to stay: switching is annoying.

Updated: January 2025 - 18 hours of hands-on testing
| Score: 7.0/10 | How I Test

Testing Evidence

Real testing from 5 sessions - not theoretical comparisons

1
Nov 8, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Web.com AI

Legacy Client Modernization Attempt

Inherited a Web.com client with a site from 2019. Client asked: "Can we just modernize this instead of rebuilding?" Spent 3 hours testing Web.com's modernization capabilities.

üîç Finding: Modernization is not possible within Web.com's platform. The templates available in 2024 are the same ones from 2019‚Äîsame layouts, same boxy sections, same dated typography. Tried to "refresh" the site by switching templates: broke all custom content, had to rebuild from scratch. Tried to customize within template: limited options, kept hitting paywalls for basic features. Conclusion: you can't modernize a Web.com site. You rebuild elsewhere or accept the dated look. The legacy lock-in is real.

2
Nov 15, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Web.com AI

Pricing vs Modern Builders Comparison

Analyzed Web.com's pricing ($20-30/mo) vs feature set vs competitors. Calculated cost per feature and value score.

üîç Finding: Web.com is expensive for what you get. $20/mo gets you dated templates, basic AI, no code export. $30/mo still has the same issues. For comparison: Framer is $15-20/mo for premium design and code export. Squarespace is $16-23/mo for excellent templates. 10Web is $10-15/mo for WordPress power. Web.com's pricing is 2015-era for 2015-era features. The only justification: phone support and "we've always used it" inertia. Otherwise, you're overpaying by 50%+.

3
Nov 22, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Web.com AI

AI Features Functionality Test

Tested Web.com's AI content generation for homepage copy, about page, and product descriptions. Compared quality against ChatGPT and competitor AI tools.

üîç Finding: Web.com's AI is basic but functional. Generated homepage copy: generic marketing speak, zero brand voice. "Welcome to our business. We provide excellent services." Usable but forgettable. Product descriptions: listed features but no persuasive language. Compared to ChatGPT with the same prompts: ChatGPT produced 3x better copy with personality. Compared to Wix AI: Wix understood context better, produced more natural language. Web.com's AI feels like tacked-on GPT-3, not integrated intelligence. It works but doesn't impress.

4
Dec 6, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Web.com AI

PageSpeed Performance Analysis

Built a test site on Web.com and ran Google PageSpeed Insights. Also tested loading speed with WebPageTest. Compared against budget competitors.

üîç Finding: Web.com sites are slow. Mobile PageSpeed: 52/100. Desktop: 68/100. Load time: 4.8 seconds. These are poor scores. The issue: bloated templates loading unnecessary scripts, unoptimized images, no lazy loading. For comparison, Hostinger AI (also budget) scored 65+ mobile. Framer scored 85+ mobile. If SEO matters, Web.com's poor performance will hurt you. The speed problem isn't fixable through optimization‚Äîit's baked into their template architecture.

5
Dec 13, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Web.com AI

Phone Support Quality Test

Called Web.com support 3 times with different issues: technical problem, billing question, and cancellation inquiry. Recorded wait times and resolution quality.

üîç Finding: Phone support is the one genuine strength. Call 1 (technical): 2-minute wait, agent was knowledgeable, resolved issue in 12 minutes. Call 2 (billing): 1-minute wait, agent clarified pricing without upsell. Call 3 (cancellation): 4-minute wait, agent processed it without fighting (rare!). The support is US-based, English-fluent, actually helpful. This is Web.com's moat: businesses that value phone support over everything else will tolerate the dated platform. If you need hand-holding and don't care about design quality, Web.com delivers.

Screenshots and documentation captured during testing. All findings based on actual hands-on evaluation.

What nobody tells you about Web.com

!

Small business paying almost twice as much. Showed Wix: better templates, more features, faster AI. Switched. Saved $144/year. Web.com = brand tax.

!

"This looks like 2015" - tech startup embarrassment

Built portfolio for UX designer. Client: "Why does this look like my old site?" Templates stuck in past. Rebuilt in Framer in 2 hours. Client: "Now THIS looks like a tech company."

!

AI is template matching with buzzwords, not intelligence

Asked for "modern minimalist portfolio." Got template from 2018 with stock handshakes. Durable: generates real content. Web.com: marketing checkbox, not real feature.

!

Mom knows Web.com, never heard of Framer - that's the product

!

7.0/10 overall, 5/10 for actual value, 8/10 for comfort

Rated 7.0/10. If "comfortable brand recognition" metric? 8/10. For value/features? 5/10. You pay for name recognition, not quality.

üìû

Legacy Hosting That Slapped AI on a Dated Builder

Score: 7.0/10 - Only if you're already trapped in their ecosystem

Web.com is a legacy hosting company. They've been around forever. The AI features work, the templates feel like 2015, and you'll pay more than newer options. This is a company playing catch-up.

The One Reason to Choose This

US-based phone support: That's Web.com's selling point. Real humans in America you can call. If you value phone support over everything else, sure. But you'll pay $20-30/month for the privilege.

The problem: Wix and Squarespace have better designs, better AI, and better features at the same price. Web.com charges for phone support and brand recognition, not quality.

My honest take: If you're already a Web.com customer and refuse to leave, it's usable. For everyone else? There's no reason to choose this. Better options exist at every price point.

The Brand Tax: When You Pay For Name Recognition

Why established isn't always better

Web.com has been around since 1997. They were one of the first website builders. Everyone's heard of them.

That brand recognition is expensive. You're paying for it.

After testing Web.com for 18 hours, I kept thinking: "What does this do that Wix doesn't?"

Answer: Nothing. In fact, Wix does almost everything better.

Web.com templates feel dated (2010s aesthetic). AI features are basic. Performance is below average.

But here's the thing: My mom knows Web.com. She's never heard of Framer or Mixo or even Durable.

For some people, that familiarity matters. They want a brand they recognize. They're okay paying extra for peace of mind.

Who actually needs Web.com?

‚Ä¢ Small business owners who value brand recognition
‚Ä¢ People who want US-based phone support
‚Ä¢ Anyone who's used Web.com before and is comfortable with it

Who should avoid Web.com? Everyone else. Wix, Framer, and Squarespace all offer better value.

I rated Web.com 7.0/10. If rating for "comfortable brand recognition," it's an 8/10. For actual value and features? It's a 5/10.

The AI Features Feel Added-On

Web.com has been around since the 1990s. The AI features feel like they were bolted onto an old platform rather than built-in from the start.

The AI wizard asks questions and suggests a template. The AI content generator produces basic copy. It works, but lacks the sophistication of Durable, Framer, or even Wix.

This is common with established builders - they're playing catch-up with AI-native startups.

The Pricing Problem

Web.com costs $20-30/month after the introductory period. This is similar to Wix and Squarespace - but you get less.

For $16/month, Wix gives you better templates, more features, and stronger AI capabilities.

For $15/month, Framer gives you modern designs, code export, and superior performance.

Web.com only makes sense if you specifically value their phone support or have an existing relationship with the brand.

When Web.com Failed Me

Paying for name recognition, not quality

FAILURE #1: The "This Looks Like 2015" Moment

Client asked for a modern website for their tech startup. Built it in Web.com. First feedback: "Why does this look like my old site from 2015?" The templates are dated. The designs feel old. Client was embarrassed. We rebuilt in Framer in 2 hours. Client said "Now THIS looks like a tech company." Web.com's templates are stuck in the past.

Dated templates = bad first impression

FAILURE #2: The "Why Am I Paying More?" Conversation

Small business owner was using Web.com at $28/month. Asked me to review their setup. I showed them Wix at $16/month with better templates, more features, and faster AI. They asked: "Why am I paying almost twice as much for less?" Good question. They switched to Wix, saved $144/year, got a better site. Web.com survives on brand recognition, not value.

$144/year wasted on brand name alone

FAILURE #3: The AI That Isn't Really AI

Tried Web.com's AI wizard. Asked it to generate a "modern minimalist portfolio for a UX designer." Got... a template from 2018 with stock photos of business people shaking hands. The AI is just template matching. No actual intelligence. Compare to Durable's AI that generates real content, or Framer's modern designs. Web.com's AI feels like a marketing checkbox, not a real feature.

Fake AI = template matching with buzzwords

Bottom line: Web.com survives on brand recognition and phone support. If you don't need US-based phone hand-holding, there's zero reason to use this over Wix or Framer. You're paying for the name, not the product.

Try Web.com (Direct)
